title: Representatives Main Committee Questions On Notice

speaker: Mr Mcgauran
theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts(2) Do any members of the Community Advisory Committee have a professional, financial or commercial interest in organisations with an association with the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust’s properties, activities or projects. (3) Are members of the Community Advisory Committee required to complete a Declaration of Conflict of Interest form. (4) Has the Sydney Harbour Federation Trust sponsored activities carried out by any members of its Community Advisory Committee; if so, which activities and what was the cost of this sponsorship. (1) No. The Community Advisory Committee (CAC) is made up of 76 members from a mixture of Commonwealth, State and local government and the general public selected for their detailed knowledge of the sites or issues relevant to the sites. Many members belong to non-government organisations and have a particular interest in the conservation of harbour lands. Members of the CAC were invited to join following an expression of interest process where interested members of the community were asked to submit their interest with details of their relevant experience. (2) Some members may have a professional, financial or commercial interest in organisations with an association with the Trust’s activities or projects, however, the CAC is not a decision making body. It cannot direct the Trust to make particular decisions. It contributes a component of the total community consultation process. It’s role is to contribute knowledge and ideas and act as a sounding board for Trust planning proposals, in particular relating to: The form and content of the plan; Specific land use issues; Strategies for the management of the Trust lands; Public access to the Trust lands; Specific Conservation issues; and The consultation process. (3) No. (4) The Sydney Harbour Federation Trust has sponsored the following activities carried out by a member of the CAC: The Trust co-sponsored a program of activities including snorkelling and introductory scuba diving as part of the Coastcare Summer Program in January 2003. CAC Member Mr W. Jones, a marine biologist and co-ordinator from the Marine Discovery Centre, presented the program. The Marine Discovery Centre is a registered environmental charity. The program was sponsored for a number of reasons being: Creating accessibility to the waters of Trusts sites which were previously not able to be accessed by the public. This assists the Trust in fulfilling our requirement’s under the Trust Act; and Allowing the Trust to become a part of the Coastcare Summer Program. The program was sponsored at a cost of $1,000. The Trust has commissioned Mrs M. Shelly-Clark, author and historian to write an essay on the History of Cockatoo Island. Mrs Shelley-Clark was selected for this work as she has specialist knowledge of Cockatoo Island as demonstrated in her book The Islands of Sydney Harbour. $3,960 was paid for this work. Preliminary work for the Cockatoo Island Conservation Management Plan was recently commissioned by the Trust. Conservation Management Plans are a necessary part of Trust activities in order to return the sites in ‘good order’ as stated in the Trust Act. The work involved a thematic presentation by Mr J. Semple Kerr in collaboration with Mr J. Jeremy, the former CEO of Cockatoo Island and CAC Member. Mr Jeremy was selected because of his special knowledge as the: Last Chief Executive of the dockyard, and Author of a comprehensive history of the dockyard Cockatoo Island “Sydney’s Historic Dockyard” published by UNSW Press in 1998. This work cost $3,000.

theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Telecommunications: Industry Ombudsman (Question No. 1350) Mrs Crosio asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 February 2003: (1) What powers does the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman have to monitor the practices of debt recovery agencies. (2) Does the Government intend to review the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman’s current power in monitoring debt recovery agencies. (3) How many complaints have been lodged with the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman in (a) 2001 and (b) 2002 regarding the practices of debt recovery agencies. (4) Is the Government aware of debt recovery agencies using fake court notices to intimidate consumers. (5) How many complaints have been lodged against Hutchinson Telecoms (Australia) Pty Ltd in 2002. (6) Has the Government been made aware of alleged unreasonable debt recovery practices and failure to keep adequate records by Hutchinson Telecoms (Australia) Pty Ltd. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) The Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (TIO) already has the authority to investigate and facilitate the resolution of complaints about credit management and debt recovery practices. The Board of the TIO has also made a decision to amend the TIO’s constitution to re-affirm its jurisdiction in debt recovery practices. This will ensure that the telecommunications company will remain responsible to its customers and to the TIO in relation to debt recovery complaints, notwithstanding that the debt may have been sold to a debt recovery company. If the TIO upholds a complaint, the TIO can make a binding determination on the telecommunications company requiring payment of compensation. If the TIO considers that there are systemic complaints about the debt recovery practices of any telecommunications company, the TIO can refer the matter to the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) or the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC). (2) No. See answer to part (1). It is also relevant that paragraph 113(3)(i) under Part6 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 states that an industry code may be developed to deal with debt collection practices. The existing Credit Management code developed under the auspices of the Australian Communications Industry Forum sets out minimum practices that must be observed by providers in this area. The code has been registered with the ACA, and the ACA may direct any noncompliant telecommunications company to comply with the code. The code is currently being revised following a public consultation process, prior to being submitted to the ACA for registration. The practice of revising industry codes every two years ensures that they address ongoing community concerns. (3) The TIO has advised that, as debt recovery agencies are not required to be members of the TIO scheme, data on complaints about these debt recovery agencies is not collected. When the TIO receives a complaint regarding the conduct of a debt recovery agency, it is recorded and taken up with the telecommunications company on whose behalf that the agency is acting. It is important to note that the figures given in (a) and (b) below relate to complaints against telecommunications companies, not debt recovery agencies. The TIO also advised that changes were made to its complaint-handling database and corresponding complaint categories at the beginning of the 2001-02 financial year. Data for credit control debt related complaints in 2000-01 and 2001-02 is not directly comparable, as data for 2000-01 covers all credit control debt related complaints, whereas data for 2001-02 relates to credit control complaints about debt recovery only. (a) In 2000-01, the TIO has advised that 3,720 credit control debt related complaints were made against telecommunications companies. (b) In 2001-02, the TIO has advised that 1,468 debt recovery credit control complaints were made against telecommunications companies. The TIO’s media release of 8 January 2003

(5) The TIO’s 2001-02 annual report identified a total of 2,493 complaints to the TIO attributed to Hutchison Telecoms (Australia) Pty Ltd. 300 complaints related to landline services and 2,193 complaints related to mobile services. Indigenous Human Remains (Question No. 1368) Mr Latham asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 February 2003: Is the Minister able to say whether, since the answer by the Minister for the Arts and Centenary of Federation to question No. 1674 (Hansard, 31 August 2000, page 19963), there have been changes to British laws which constrain certain government funded institutions, such as the British Museum and the British Natural History Museum, from returning collection items. The question was transferred to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs on the 13 February 2003. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The British Government has not yet amended its legislation to enable publicly funded museums and other institutions to return collection items. The British Government established the UK Working Group on Human Remains following the release of the Prime Ministerial Joint Statement on Aboriginal Remains on 4 July 2000. That Working Group, chaired by Professor Norman Palmer, is examining the current legal status of human remains kept in government funded museums and galleries in the United Kingdom. It is expected that the Working Group will report its findings to the British Parliament towards the middle of this year. Indigenous Human Remains (Question No. 1369) Mr Latham asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 5 February 2003: (1) In their joint statement on 4 July 2000 did the British and Australian Prime Ministers welcome the initiative of the British Natural History Museum in cataloguing the 450 indigenous human remains in its collection and in providing this information to the Australian Government. (2) Have any of the Museum’s human remains been returned to Australia. ber’s question: (1) Yes, in their joint statement, the British and Australian Prime Ministers welcomed the British Natural History Museum’s initiative to catalogue Australian Indigenous human remains held in its collection and provide that information to the Australian Government. (2) No human remains have been returned to Australia from the British Natural History Museum. Commonwealth Funded Programs (Question No. 1486) Ms Grierson asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 13 February 2003: (1) Does the Minister’s Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle can apply for funding; if so, what are the programs. (2) Does the Minister’s Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print or other media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements. (3) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), (a) what is its purpose and (b) who is responsible for allocating funds. (4) With respect to each of the Commonwealth funded programs referred to in part (1), how many (a) community organisations, (b) business or (c) individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002. (5) What sum of Commonwealth funding did each recipient receive in 2001 and 2002. (6) What is the name and address of each recipient. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: The Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts offers the residents of the electorate of Newcastle a wide range of benefits across both its cultural and information and communications program streams. These various programs are described in this answer so that they correspond with the structure of the department. ARTS AND SPORT PROGRAMS Visions of Australia (1) Yes, Visions of Australia. (2) Yes, the funding opportunities are advertised. (a) Advertisements are placed in major metropolitan papers plus the Koori Mail; Industry journals such as Museums Australia and Art Monthly. (b) Yes, they are paid advertisements. (3) (a) The purposes of the Visions of Australia program is to provide all Australians with access to high quality exhibitions of cultural material. It provides grants to cultural and community organisations to develop and tour exhibitions of historical and scientific material visual arts and craft, multimedia and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture throughout Australia. Exhibitions should have a predominantly Australian source or theme. (b) A ten-member committee appointed by the Federal Minister for the Arts and Sport considers applications. The Visions of Australia Committee meets twice a year, after the close of each grant rounds, to consider the applications on a competitive basis against the assessment criteria and in the context of available funds. The Minister approves grants on the recommendation of the Committee. The Department administers the program. (4) (a) No community organisations in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002. (b) The Newcastle Region Art Gallery received funding in 2001. (c) No individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle received funding in 2001 and 2002.

theText: The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts(5) The Newcastle Region Art Gallery received $40,000 in 2001. Regional Policy and Programs (1) Yes Playing Australia Festivals Australia Contemporary Music Touring Program (2) Yes (a) Each program has two grant rounds per year. A paid block advertisement is placed in all major metropolitan dailies, including The Weekend Australian and The Sydney Morning Herald. These advertisements, under the heading of ‘Cultural Touring Grants’ appear either in the early general news section or the arts pages, usually in late May and late October, after the announcement of successful applicants for the previous round. Festivals Australia rounds are also advertised in more than 60 regional newspapers, 21 of them in New South Wales, including the Newcastle Herald and the Maitland Mercury. This program is also advertised in the NSW & ACT, Special Events Directory. Advertisements are also placed in a number of local government publications on an ad hoc basis. Additional advertisements for the Contemporary Music Touring Program are placed in a selection of ‘street press’ and music industry journals. Information on all programs is accessible of the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts website. State and Territory arts ministries, and Regional Arts Organisations, provide information on the programs via their own publications and/or via website links. (b) Newspaper advertising is paid advertising. Some local government publication advertising is free, as is website information. (3) (a) Playing Australia is the Commonwealth Government’s National Performing Arts Touring Program. It is designed to assist the touring of performing arts across State and Territory boundaries where this is currently not commercially viable and there is a demonstrated public demand. Festivals Australia is a funding program designed to assist the presentation of arts and cultural activities at Australian regional and community festivals. The emphasis is on supporting projects which adds to the quality and diversity of the arts and cultural programming of a festival. The Contemporary Music Touring Program aims to develop viable touring opportunities within Australia for Australian musicians, and to increase audience access to live Australian contemporary music, particularly in rural and regional Australia. (b) Expert technical committees, broadly representative of the sector, make recommendations after assessing applications in each round. These are forwarded to the Minister for the Arts and Sport for consideration and approval. (4) (a) Two community organisations received funding in 2001 and 2002. (b) No businesses received funding in 2001 and 2002. (c) No individuals received funding in 2001 and 2002. (5) This Is Not Art received $10,000 under the Festivals Australia program in 2002. Cultures in Actions received $4,000 under the Festivals Australia program in 2002. (6) This Is Not Art 3/231 King Street Cultures in Action PO Box 522 Networking the Nation (1) Yes. In the past, community organisations could apply for funding through the Commonwealth Networking the Nation (NTN) program (although individuals and for-profit businesses were not eligible NTN applicants.) These funds have now all been allocated. (2) Over the life of the NTN Program the advertising requirements changed. As more applications were received, the need for promotional advertising has been reduced. In those States where NTN funds were fully committed (this includes NSW), the Program was not promoted. (a) Advertisements for the NTN Program have in the past been placed in a range of newspapers including “The Australian”, “The Broken Hill Barrier Truth”, “Bourke Western Herald”, “The Land” and the “Koori Times”. There were a number of advertisements placed in specialist publications including the “Australian Local Government Association Yearbook” and the “NT Cattleman’s Association Yearbook”. In addition, the Program was promoted on the ments. (b) The NTN Program has promoted the program through a number of media outlets using a mixture of paid and unpaid advertisements. (3) (a) The objective of Networking the Nation Program is to assist the economic and social development of regional, rural and remote Australia by funding projects which: enhance telecommunications infrastructure and services in regional, rural and remote areas; increase access to, and promote use of, services available thruogh telecommunications networks in regional, rural and remote areas; or reduce disparities in access to such services and facilities between Australians in regional, rural or remote areas and those in urban areas. ‘Regional, rural and remote areas’ are any areas located outside the capital city of each State or Territory. (b) The NTN Board approves funding, which is then released in instalments through funding Deeds administered between recipients and the NTN Secretariat in Canberra. (4) (a) Five NTN projects were managed by community organisations based in the electoral division of Newcastle. All of these projects benefited the broader Hunter region, including the electoral division of Newcastle. No NTN projects benefited only the electoral division of Newcastle. (b) No businesses received funding. (c) No individuals received funding. (5) The only payment in either 2001 or 2002 to the Hunter Telemedicine project was the final instalment of $26,400 in February 2002 out of the total project funding of $864,628. The only payment in either 2001 or 2002 to the Hunter Tourism E-Commerce project was the final instalment of $14,000 in June 2001 out of the total project funding of $304,000. The only payment in either 2001 or 2002 to the Hunter Internet Access Exchange project was the final instalment of $3,000 in February 2001 out of the total project funding of $21,000. Payments to the Hunter Region Online project totalled $160,000 in 2001 and $50,000 in 2002, as the final instalments of the total project funding of $400,000. Payments to the Networking the Hunter IT Coordinator project totalled $40,000 in 2001 and $2,500 in 2002, as the final instalments of the total project funding of $90,000. The recipient for the Hunter Telemedicine project was the Hunter Area Health Service, which had the registered address of Lookout Road, NEW LAMBTON NSW 2305. (6) The recipient for the Hunter Tourism E-Commerce project was the Hunter Regional Tourism Organisation, which had the registered address of Level 1, 45 Hunter Street, NEWCASTLE NSW 2300. The recipient for the Hunter Internet Access Exchange project was the Hunter Internet Access Exchange, which had the registered address of Unit 2, 80 Grinsell Street, KOTARA NSW 2289. The recipient for the Hunter Region Online project was the Newcastle & Hunter Business Chamber, which had the registered address of 475 Hunter Street, NEWCASTLE NSW 2302. The recipient for the Networking the Hunter IT Coordinator project was the Hunter Economic Development Corporation, which had the registered address of Level 3, 251 Wharf Road, Telecommunications Consumer Representation and Research Grants (1) Yes. The Department administers the Telecommunications Consumer Representation and Research Grants. These grants are administered under Section 593 of the Telecommunications Act 1997. (2) Yes. (a) The Grants are advertised annually, usually in March, in the major metropolitan newspapers. (b) They are paid advertisements. (3) (a) The Consumer Representation grants are provided to consumer bodies for the purpose of representation of the interests of consumers in relation to telecommunications issues. The Research grants are provided to individuals or a body for purposes in connection with research into the social, economic, environmental or technological implications of developments relating to telecommunications. (b) The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. (4) (a) No grants were made to community organisations in the electoral division of Newcastle in 2001 and 2002. (b) No grants were made to businesses in the electoral division of Newcastle in 2001 and 2002. (c) No grants were made to individuals in the electoral division of Newcastle in 2001 and 2002. (5) Not Applicable. (6) Not Applicable. Television Black Spots Program (1) Yes. Television Black Spots Program (TVBSP). (2) Yes. (a) The TVBSP was initially advertised after Round1 was announced on 21 June 2000, with advertisements placed in two national papers and 34 regional papers across the country. Information kits were sent to 642 local shires and councils at that time inviting all local governments to apply for funding under the Program. The Program was also widely advertised following the announcement of Round2 on 1 November 2000, with advertisements placed in three national and 75 regional newspapers. Revised information kits were also sent to the 642 local shires and councils at that time. A final round of ‘reminder’ advertising followed in February 2001, with advertisements placed in the Weekend Australian and 65 regional newspapers. (b) These were paid advertisements. (3) (a) The Federal Government, in recognising the difficulties that some communities, particularly those outside of capital cities, were having in getting access to free-to-air television services, established the $35 million TVBSP, which is one component of the $120 million Television Fund, funded from the sale of the second tranche of Telstra. The TVBSP aims to assist communities to fix between 200-250 television black spots by funding the capital cost of ‘self-help’ analog retransmission facilities (up to $25,000 per television service, including up to $2,000 to cover the cost of the technical survey, and up to $25,000 for site establishment costs). (b) All communities across Australia were eligible to apply for funding under the TVBSP. All applicants that applied under the TVBSP and met the Program’s Guidelines were eligible for funding. The Minister is responsible for approving recommendations for funding made by the TV Fund Unit in the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts. (4) (a) No applications were received under the TVBSP for the electorate of Newcastle. (b) No applications from businesses were received under the TVBSP for the electorate of Newcastle. (c) No applications from individuals were received under the TVBSP for the electorate of Newcastle. (5) Not Applicable. (6) Not Applicable. theText: The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:Telecommunications: Television Black Spot Program (Question No. 1558) Ms Jann McFarlane asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 4 March 2003: (1) Will the Minister provide details, by electorate, listing which areas have received funds from the Television Black Spots Program. (2) How much of the money allocated under the Television Black Spots Program has been spent. (3) Which areas in Western Australia have received funds from rounds 1 or 2 of the Television Black Spots Program. (4) What percentage of the Television Black Spots Program funding was allocated to the capital cities. has provided the following answer to the honourable member’s question: (1) 62 electorates covering 464 black spot areas have received funds from the Television Black Spots Program (TVBSP) see Table A. (2) To date, $14.3 million of the $35 million allocated has been spent under the TVBSP. (3) In Western Australia, 50 black spot areas have received funds under the TVBSP see Table B. (4) The TVBSP is a needs-based program, relying on applications from communities with poor television reception, and therefore there was no specific allocation to any electorate, state or capital city. Eligible metropolitan applications were received from East Perth in Western Australia, Geelong and Monbulk in Victoria, and Wollongong and Woronora in New South Wales.
